block.p: Spymaster's Whereabouts Dominates Talk in Peru There were conflicting reports of the whereabouts and status of Vladimir Montesinos, Peru's intelligence chief. Mr. Montesinos, shown on a videotape last week apparently offering a congressman a bribe, is at the heart of the uproar that has led the president to announce the dismantling of the intelligence service and elections in which he will not seek office.

Bomber Was C.I.A. Informer The former chief of Chile's secret police, Gen. Manuel Contreras Sepulveda, who was convicted of masterminding a lethal car bombing in downtown Washington in 1976, was a C.I.A. informer at the time the bombing occurred, documents show.

Spymaster's Whereabouts Dominates Talk in Peru There were conflicting reports of the whereabouts and status of Vladimir Montesinos, Peru's intelligence chief. Mr. Montesinos, shown on a videotape last week apparently offering a congressman a bribe, is at the heart of the uproar that has led the president to announce the dismantling of the intelligence service and elections in which he will not seek office.

Bomber Was C.I.A. Informer The former chief of Chile's secret police, Gen. Manuel Contreras Sepulveda, who was convicted of masterminding a lethal car bombing in downtown Washington in 1976, was a C.I.A. informer at the time the bombing occurred, documents show.

U.S. Presses Russia on Lasers The United States was said to be pressing Russia not to proceed with plans to sell Iran laser technology that Washington says can be used to make fuel for nuclear weapons.

Poor Training for Kosovo Cited An Army inquiry into reports of American soldiers' abusing of civilians found that many of the peacekeepers had had little training in policing and in dealing with ethnic tensions.
Warning to Indonesia Defense Secretary William S. Cohen told Indonesian officials that they faced diplomatic and economic reprisals if the militias causing havoc on Timor were not disbanded.

China's Long Wait Ends China won the team gold medal in men's gymnastics, its first in that event in 40 years. In swimming, Pieter van den Hoogenband beat Ian Thorpe in the 200-meter freestyle, and Lenny Krayzelburg won the gold in the 100-meter backstroke.

Western Governors Sign On To Federal Wildfire Plan Governors from Western states devastated by wildfires this summer met with the Interior and Agriculture secretaries and endorsed a Clinton administration firefighting plan to put a new emphasis on prevention and local decision-making.

Los Angeles Transit Strike A half-million commuters were left stranded on the third day, and the first work day, of the strike. Officials reported a 5 percent increase in morning rush hour freeway traffic, taxi drivers said business had doubled, and streets were clogged.

Bush Courts Middle Class Gov. George W. Bush opened a six-day, nine-state drive to showcase proposals intended to appeal to middle-income Americans, asserting that his tax cut plan would relieve the pressure on parents who work more than one job.

A21 Dick Cheney, sharply questioned by voters and students, sought to allay concerns that Governor Bush's proposal to withhold federal funds from low-performing schools and give the money directly to parents would damage public schools.
Gore on Women's Health Care Vice President Al Gore promoted his plans for improving women's health care and accepted the Teamsters' endorsement at their convention.

Warning on Drug Benefit Plan The White House expressed alarm at the possibility that Congress might provide money to the states to help low-income elderly people buy prescription drugs, as Gov. George W. Bush has proposed. Administration officials asserted that such an approach would be unworkable.

United Way President Out Betty S. Beene resigned as president of the United Way of America. The organization is caught up in a power struggle with a number of large United Ways over a plan championed by Mrs. Beene that would shift the processing of donations away from regional organizations to a national pledge-processing center.

$80 Million Gift to Museum A California developer and philanthropist, Kenneth E. Behring, plans to donate $80 million to modernize the National Museum of American History, the largest single donation to the Smithsonian, officials said.

Office Space at a Premium; Rents Reach Record Highs A severe lack of office space is challenging New York City's ability to retain corporate headquarters and attract new businesses, according to urban planners, executives, developers and political officials. Manhattan landlords have raised rents to record levels, with Midtown rents up nearly 30 percent in the last year.

Bloomberg Leans Toward Move Bloomberg, the financial information company, was said to have agreed to become the anchor tenant for a proposed 1.3 million-square-foot, 75-story tower on Lexington Avenue at 59th Street, site of the old Alexander's department store.

Region's Job Growth Surges Private employment and job creation in the New York region hit an all-time high in 1999, surpassing the national rate of job growth for the first time in nearly two decades, a Port Authority study found.

Charitable Donations Disclosed Jon S. Corzine, the Democratic Senate candidate from New Jersey, said he gave more than $10 million to dozens of charities since last year, with $100,000 going to groups whose leaders or sponsors later endorsed him. He said there was no link between his donations and his campaign.
Jail Health Care Contract New York City is negotiating a three-year contract with Prison Health Services of Brentwood, Tenn., to provide health care on Rikers Island.
Decline in Hand-Washing A study said 54 percent of women and 43 percent of men washed their hands after using bathrooms in Grand Central and Penn Station.

Government Scientists' Exodus The technology boom and other factors are leading scientists away from government labs and into the private sector, where they say the rewards are much greater. Administrators fear the quality of government-sponsored research may suffer.
Mental Effects of Heart Surgery Doctors say evidence is mounting that a small but significant number of coronary artery-bypass patients suffer cognitive impairment.

Rise in Fatal Tire Crashes The number of fatal accidents involving Ford Explorers with tire problems more than doubled last year, to 40, after rising steadily since the mid-1990's, a trend that indicates that the overall death toll from defective Firestone tires is higher than previously reported.
Ford and Continental were said to be discussing with federal regulators plans to replace a Continental tire model that has had tread problems on Lincoln Navigators.

AOL-Time Warner Deal European antitrust regulators are threatening to block the $165 billion merger of Time Warner and America Online out of concern for competition in the online distribution of music and entertainment.
Euro's Fall Cuts U.S. Profits The euro continued its decline, to 85.46 cents, as the effects of the currency's weakness touched the American corporate landscape, cutting into sales and profits.
Editorials: Mr. Bush's new strategy; the shadowy politics of Peru; a ban on assisted suicides; boys of autumn.
Columns: Thomas L. Friedman, Gail Collins.
